descriptionSet.description: The four-armed goddess Lakshmi, wearing a pink sari and holding two pink lotus flowers, is depicted here. In the background one can see an elephant bathing and four swans swimming in a lake. Two boxes of Sandalwood Soap are depicted in the lower left corner.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: 1940
text-en: CALICUT, INDIA.
text-en: KERALA Sandalwood Soap
text-en: INDIA'S FAVOURITE

description-en: The four-armed goddess Lakshmi, wearing a pink sari and holding two pink lotus flowers, is depicted here. In the background one can see an elephant bathing and four swans swimming in a lake. Two boxes of Sandalwood Soap are depicted in the lower left corner. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Varma places the four-armed goddess, clad in a light rose sari, in a natural setting. The lotus rises from a calm lake fed by a stream in the background that descends from mountains still further in the rear of the image. Lakshmi addresses the viewer with a direct gaze and a placid, benign expression. (This clean design, originally produced by the Ravi Varma Press and distributed in date, has here been adapted in a 1940 calendar for Kerala Sandalwood Soap.) Varma’s iconic two-dimensional images were frequently framed, and sometimes decorated by devout owners with glued-on sequins and new cloth saris, just as a three-dimensional statue in a shrine would be dressed and adorned for worship by priests or householders. (Richard H. Davis) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Like other products, these advertisements on calenders invoked devotional and mythological imagery to sell soap. Gods and goddesses were their first models. (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The connection between Hindu Gods and soap through the motiv of pureness is more than obvious. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This calendar was based on a well-known Raja Ravi Varma paintings. Scholars have point outed that many "pirate" versions of his images would circulate repetitively in calendars over time. (Sabeena Gadihoke) (gs)
related literature: Davis, Richard H. 2010. "Temple in a Frame. God Posters For and Of Worship", http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/97/index.html, last accessed 2011-01-09 (gs)
